uk.ac.cam.darknet.backend

Interface DataCollector

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    FacebookDataCollector, ManualInputDataCollector, PrimaryDataCollector, SecondaryDataCollector

    public interface DataCollector
extends java.lang.Runnable
    An interface for data collectors. Data collectors harvest data from the Internet, parse/process it and save it in a database.
    Author:
    Augustin Zidek

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String getCollectorId()
      Each collector must have a unique ID across the system.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.lang.Runnable

        run

    • Method Detail

      • setup

        void setup(java.util.List<Individual> individuals)
        This method is used to setup the collector before it is run in its own thread. Primary data collectors do not need to implement this and should return immediately.
        Parameters:
        individuals - The list of individuals, containing only basic information, whose data should be looked up.

      • getTypeTable

        java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,AttributeCategories> getTypeTable()
        This method returns a table of the attributes that this collector supports. The table is a set of key-value pairs, with each key being a string equal to the name of the attribute, and each value being an AttributeCategory. The returned Hashtable object may for example contain the following key-value pairs:
        Attribute Name Global Attribute Type
        twitter.username GlobalAttributeType.USER_NAME
        twitter.displaypic GlobalAttributeType.PHOTO
        ... ...
        The data collection manager will build the global attribute table by combining the attribute tables returned by each collector.
        Returns:
        A Properties object containing all the attributes supported with their global types.

      • getCollectorId

        java.lang.String getCollectorId()
        Each collector must have a unique ID across the system. The IDs should only contain letters and numbers and are case-insensitive. If two collectors claim the same ID, the data collection manager may refuse to use them.
        Returns:
        The unique ID of the collector.
